jb:CoverPage.jb:Title: Tactical and Support Vehicles, Budget Activity 1

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: Tactical trailers and dolly sets are used to transport generators, shelters, drinking water, ammunition, and general cargo. This budget line funds the Light Engineer Utility Trailer (LEUT), Light Tactical Trailer (LTT), and the Heavy Expanded Mobility Ammunition Trailer (HEMAT). The prime movers for these trailers range from the High Mobility Multi-Purpose Wheeled Vehicle (HMMWV) to the 10-Ton M977 Series Heavy Expanded Mobility Tactical Truck (HEMTT). The Light Engineer Utility Trailer (LEUT) is a pintle towed light utility trailer. The LEUT will be used across the full spectrum of military operations to include deployments and to support nation-building operations. The LEUT will transport key construction enablers such as Skid Steer Loaders (SSL) and Backhoe Loaders (BHL). Two types of LEUTs are required. Type I LEUT is a 5-ton payload capacity trailer of which must be Low Velocity Air Drop (LVAD) capable. Type II LEUT is a 12-ton payload capacity trailer. The prime movers for the Type I and Type II LEUT are the HEMTT, 2.5 ton cargo, 5-ton cargo, and 5, 10, and 20-ton dump trucks. The Army Acquisition Objective for the LEUT is 2,563 (Type I: 1,359 and Type II: 1,204).
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $3.733 million supports the procurement of 30 Type I LEUTs and 25 Type II LEUTs to include manuals, transportation, and fielding. As of July 2014, Acquisition Strategy has changed; test articles and LRIP quantities will now include Type I trailers. The LEUT will provide engineer units with a critically needed dedicated small equipment transport capability. With the LEUT's ability to transport key construction enablers, the LEUT will allow future force units the ability to gain, control and sustain route access in a timely manner and effectively maintain momentum/mobility throughout the battlespace. The FY 2017 funding request was reduced by $2.000 million to account for the availability of prior year execution balances.
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: Light Equipment Utility Trailer
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: PM/Matrix Support includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and provide contractor oversight. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other government costs are included for retaining a professional acquisition workforce.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The M870 series of Low-Bed Semitrailers, of which the M870A4 is the newest model, is a 40-ton mechanical folding gooseneck and a level deck with rear ramps capable of handling payloads on primary, secondary, and trail profiles. The semitrailer is a multi-axle trailer with vehicle front and rear end loading capability, 24 volt electrical system including light emitting diode (LED) lights and extensions to expand the trailer width. The semitrailer is connected to its prime mover, M983A4 Light Equipment Transporter (LET) Tractor, via a 3.5-inch king pin. The primary mission of the M870A4 is to transport engineering equipment, as well as pavers, compactors, the Hydraulic Excavator (HYEX) and dozers.
The Semi Trailer Low Bed (STLB) is a 25-ton payload capacity semitrailer with a fixed goose neck, step deck and rear loading ramps. It is interoperable with a variety of truck tractors and is employed to transport construction equipment, miscellaneous equipment, disabled equipment, Class IV construction materials and logistical provisions.
The M871A3 Semitrailer is a 22.5-ton drop deck/break bulk (DD/BB) container transporter. It is a tactical, dual purpose, bulk and container transporter. It transports 20-foot International Standardization for Organization (ISO) containers on line haul missions and is the primary means of distributing containers and bulk cargo.
The M872A4 Semitrailer is a 34-ton dual purpose, break bulk container transporter. The semitrailer has a maximum rated payload of 68,000 pounds and is capable of a daily operating range of at least 300 miles at sustained speeds of 50-60 miles per hour.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $3.716 million supports the production and testing of 11 Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) M870A4s. The 11 LRIP trailers will undergo Production Verification Testing (PVT) for 15 months. Testing will be completed by 2QFY20. Ongoing Systems Engineering/Program Management (SEPM) support for system engineering, logistics, testing, and product integration will be required.
FY 2017 OCO procurement dollars in the amount of $4.180 million funds the production of 38 M870A4s for the Combatant Command (COCOM) requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries in support of the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI).
IAW Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: SEMITRAILER LB 40T M870A1 (CCE)
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks:
The Acquisition Strategy was revised to include 1) requiring third party independent market survey, 2) creating trade space in the design for several requirements, 3) offering technical credit for items during Source Selection Evaluation Board (SSEB), and 4) scheduling a competitive run-off test prior to execution of Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) delivery order.
Two contractors will be awarded an Indefinite Delivery Indefinite Quantity (IDIQ) contract for two trailers each for the run-off test from SSEB process. Evaluation of Fair Opportunity Submission Request (FOSR) will result in an award to one contractor for LRIP. Begin Production Verification Test (PVT) in FY19. Complete PVT, Developmental Test/Operational Test (DT/OT) and Log Demo in FY20. Begin Full Rate Production (FRP) in FY21.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Army National Guard (ARNG) and US Army Reserves (USAR) requires its existing older High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle (HMMWV) fleet be modernized to the current configuration. The ARNG and USAR requires new M997A3 Ambulances. PD, Light Tactical Vehicles, in partnership with Rock Island Arsenal, provides new production ambulances; supporting both the organic and industrial base. Recent natural disasters highlight the need for reliable and capable utility vehicles to enable the Guard and Reserve to mobilize rapidly to respond immediately to state and national needs.
Congress added FY2016 funds in this program that were realigned from SSN D12020, HMMWV Modernization ARNG.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
There are no FY 2017 Base procurement requirements for this program.
"In accordance with section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181) this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities."

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: AMBULANCE, 4 LITTER,5/4 TON,4X4
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: PM/Matrix Support includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and provide contractor oversight. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other government costs are included for retaining a professional workforce.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: The Ground Mobility Vehicle (GMV) (formerly called the Ultra Light Combat Vehicle) provides enhanced tactical mobility for an Infantry Brigade Combat Team (IBCT) 9-Soldier infantry squad with their associated equipment to move quickly around the battlefield, including the ability to execute medium distance insertion operations using UH-60 aircraft, providing commanders greater freedom of movement and freedom of action. This capability provides flexibility for entry operations (permissive and non-permissive) to counter threat anti-access strategies by using multiple austere entry points via air-drop, air-land, and/or air-insertion to bring in combat configured units.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $4.907 million supports the procurement of 10 GMVs to support a low rate initial production (LRIP) build, testing, logistics and engineering support, testing and program management. The GMV is a critical program in the Combat Vehicle Modernization Strategy. The GMVs mobility coupled with speed will substantially increase IBCT tactical employment options and rapidly deploy infantry elements to positions of advantage.
There is no approved Army Acquisition Objective (AAO). The CPD is in 1&2 star staffing with a draft AAO of 975. The approved production quantity is 150 vehicles.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: Ground Mobility Vehicles (Light) GMV (L)
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: PM/Matrix Support includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and provide contractor oversight. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other government costs are included for retaining a professional workforce.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Army National Guard (ARNG) requires its existing older High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle (HMMWV) fleet be modernized to the current configuration. The vehicle upgrades will include vehicle reliability enhancements incorporated into HMMWV production during Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom to allow for installation of armor packages, by inclusion of improved suspension and vehicle cooling system enhancements. The modernization effort will consist of vehicle disassembly and reassembly, application of designated mandatory replacement parts and compliance requirements, installation of Automotive Improvement Program and Reliability Enhancement Vehicle components, and Inspection and Repair Only as Necessary (IROAN) of the HMMWV cab. The cab will be integrated onto a new production rolling chassis to include a new engine, engine cooling system, transmission, and suspension system. Currently a Public Private Partnership (PPP) exists for the ARNG HMMWV Modernization Program that workloads and supports both the organic and industrial base. The ARNG also requires new M997A3 Ambulances. PD, Light Tactical Vehicles, in partnership with Rock Island Arsenal, provides new production ambulances; supporting both the organic and industrial bases.
Congress added FY 2016 funds for this program for HMMWV Ambulance that was realigned to SSN D15406, Ambulance, 4 Litter, 5/4 Ton 4X4.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
There are no FY 2017 Base procurement requirements for this program.
"In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181) this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities."

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: HMMWV MODERNIZATION ARNG
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: PM/Matrix Support includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and provide contractor oversight. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other government costs are included for retaining a professional workforce.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Joint Light Tactical Vehicle (JLTV) Family of Vehicles (FoV) is a United States Army (USA) lead, joint program with the U.S. Marine Corps (USMC). The JLTV goal is the procurement of 49,099 vehicles, of various configurations, capable of performing multiple mission roles and designed to provide protected, sustained, networked mobility for personnel and payloads across the full range of military operations. JLTV objectives include increased protection and performance over the current fleet; and, minimizing ownership costs by maximizing commonality, fuel efficiency, reliability, and maintaining effective competition throughout the life cycle. Commonality of components, maintenance procedures, training, etc., among vehicles is expected to be inherent in FoV solutions across mission variants to minimize total ownership cost. Unique service requirements have been minimized.
The Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO) is 49,099 trucks for the U.S. Army.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $587.514 million supports a quantity of 1,828 JLTV's of various configurations to fulfill the requirements of multiple mission roles and minimize ownership costs for the Army's Light Tactical Vehicle fleet. Other FY 2017 budget activities include kit procurement, program management, contractor systems engineering/program management (SEPM), System Technical Support (STS), Training Aids, Devices, Simulators and Simulation (TADSS). Funding also supports the continuation of the JLTV test program to include Production Qualification Test (PQT), and Reliability Qualification Test (RQT) in support of Initial Operational Capability (IOC); scheduled for FY 2020. Increase in support costs from FY16 to FY17 due to the increased production of JLTV (1,142 additional vehicles).
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: JOINT LIGHT TACTICAL VEHICLE
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: On 8 September 2015, a Stop Work Order was issued to Oshkosh after a protest was filed with the Government Accountability Office (GAO). On 15 December 2015, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) dismissed the protest due to Lockheed Martin's notice that they intended to file a Post-Award Bid Protest with the U.S. Court of Federal Claims (COFC). The Stop Work Order was officially cancelled and Oshkosh has resumed work. On 17 December 2015 Lockheed Martin officially filed a complaint with the U.S. Court of Federal Claims (COFC) and an injunction is pending. JPO JLTV is currently evaluating potential injunction impacts.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The M917A3 22.5 ton Heavy Dump Truck (HDT) is a commercially based system used to load, transport, and dump payloads of sand and gravel aggregates, crushed rock, hot paving mixes, earth, clay, rubble, and large boulders at engineering and construction sites under worldwide climatic conditions in a military environment. The HDT integrated armor requirement is compliant with the Tactical Wheeled Vehicle Long Term Armor Strategy (LTAS) Ballistic Specifications, v3.7, dated 19 Jan 06. The HDT is required to replace the F5070, M917 and M917A1 HDTs with the oldest fielded variants at 50 years of age.
The Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO) is 1,154 vehicles.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $3.927 million procures a quantity of 4 Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) assets and Production Verification Testing (PVT).
Systems Engineering Program Management (SEPM) includes PM and System Engineering support required to conduct requirements analysis, specification development, program management and contractor oversight. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other Government costs are included for retaining a professional acquisition workforce.
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: TRUCK, DUMP, 20T (CCE)
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: Heavy Dump Truck (HDT) Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) build is to begin 3QFY18 followed by Product Verification Testing (PVT) in FY19. Concurrent armor development is to begin 2QFY18. Armored solution testing will run 2QFY20 through 2QFY21 and production will begin 1QFY22.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Family of Medium Tactical Vehicles (FMTV) is a complete series of trucks and trailers, based on a common chassis, that vary by payload and mission. The Light Medium Tactical Vehicle (LMTV) has a 2-1/2-ton capacity consisting of cargo and van models. The Medium Tactical Vehicle (MTV) has a 5-ton capacity, consisting of cargo, tractor, van, wrecker, load handling system, and dump truck models. Sub-variants provide Air Drop capability for contingency and rapid deployment operations. Commonality between variants significantly reduces operation and maintenance costs. FMTV performs over 55% of the Army's local, line haul, and unit resupply missions in combat, combat support, and combat service support units. Extended applications of the FMTV include support to other Army requirements such as: High Mobility Artillery Rocket System (HIMARS); Warfighter Information Network - Tactical (WIN-T); Patriot; Aviation Ground Support Equipment (AGSE); Chemical and Biological Protection Shelter (CBPS); Medium Extended Air Defense System (MEADS); CAMEL II Unit Water Pod System; Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD); and EQ-36 Fire Finder Radar. FMTV trailers (LMTV & MTV) have the same payload as the LMTV/MTV trucks.
The Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO) is 83,185 trucks: 45,090 MTV trucks, 38,095 LMTV trucks.
Prior year quantities through FY 2010 reflect trucks only. Beginning in FY 2011, quantities reflect trucks and trailers calculated at different unit prices.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base Procurement dollars in the amount of $53.293 million supports a full and open contract to be awarded in April 2017 for a quantity of 26 trucks and 5 trailers for First Article Test (FAT) and 8 various Medium Tactical Vehicle Trucks to fill the 5-ton truck requirement, fulfill Army modularity requirements and modernize the medium fleet, reduce operating and support costs, resolve potential operational deficiencies and operate throughout the area of operation as a multi-purpose transportation vehicle used by combat, combat support and combat service support units. PM/Matrix Support includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and provide contractor oversight. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other government costs are included for retaining a profession acquisition workforce.
FY17 OCO Procurement dollars includes $299.476 million to support the COCOM requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries and support the European Reassurance Initiatives. The procurements includes a quantity of 1,102 various capable trucks in the establishment of six Armored Brigade Combat Team (ABCT) for European Reassurance Initiative (ERI) - Army Preposition Set (APS). Procurement is necessary to outfit the Pre-Positioned equipment set. There is no excess inventory or viable substitute available to support the ERI requirement. Army Preposition Set (APS) must be filled with trucks that meet armoring requirements.
The following SSNs below roll-up to the parent SSN:
LIGHT MEDIUM TACTICAL VEHICLE TRAILER D03500 There are no FY 2017 Base Procurement funding requirements for this program. There are no FY 2017 OCO Procurement funding requirements for this program
MEDIUM TACTICAL VEHICLE TRAILER D04500 There are no FY 2017 Base Procurement funding requirements for this program. There are no FY 2017 OCO Procurement funding requirements for this program.
LIGHT MEDIUM TACTICAL VEHICLE FAMILY D13500 There are no FY 2017 Base Procurement funding requirements for this program.
FY17 OCO Procurement dollars in the amount of $40.931 million supports a quantity of 179 various LMTV armor capable trucks to fill the requirement of establishing Armored Brigade Combat Team (ABCT) Army Preposition Set (APS) as part of the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI).
MEDIUM TACTICAL VEHICLE FAMILY D14500 FY 2017 Base Procurement dollars in the amount of $53.293 million supports a full and open contract to be awarded in April 2017 for a quantity of 26 trucks and 5 trailers for First Article Test (FAT) and 8 various armor capable MTV trucks to fill the 5-ton truck requirement and modernize the medium fleet, reduce operating costs, resolve potential operational deficiencies and operate throughout the area of operation as a multi-purpose transportation vehicle used by combat, combat support, and combat service support units.
FY17 OCO Procurement dollars in the amount of $258.545 million supports a quantity of 923 various MTV armor capable trucks to fill the requirement of establishing an Armored Brigade Combat Team (ABCT) Army Preposition Set (APS) as part of the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI).
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: LIGHT MEDIUM TACT VEHICLE FAMILY (4X4)
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: FY17 OCO Procurement dollars in the amount of $40.931 million supports a quantity of 179 various LMTV armor capable trucks to fill the requirement of establishing Armored Brigade Combat Team (ABCT) Army Preposition Set (APS) as part of the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI).

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: MEDIUM TACT VEHICLE FAMILY (6X6)
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks:
FY 2017 Base Procurement dollars in the amount of $53.293 million supports a full and open contract to be awarded in April 2017 for a quantity of 26 trucks and 5 trailers for First Article Test (FAT) and 8 various armor capable MTV trucks.
FY17 OCO Procurement dollars in the amount of $258.545 million supports a quantity of 923 various MTV armor capable trucks to fill the requirement of establishing Armored Brigade Combat Team (ABCT) Army Preposition Set (APS) as part of the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI).

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: This line is a roll-up of various Fire Trucks. These vehicles are used for fighting fires, and as a safety precaution at airfields and ammunition storage areas. In addition, these vehicles respond to forest fires, train and automobile accidents, and hazardous material incidents. These vehicles are essential to all military installations and to many local communities for the preservation of life and property. Non-tactical Fire Trucks is a vehicle replacement program that does not have a set Army Acquisition Objective (AAO).
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $7.460 million supports Army installations and units with fire fighting protection and emergency response capability. A total of 16 Non-Tactical Fire Trucks are needed to replace over-aged trucks and fill existing shortages. Many over age trucks are unsafe, unable to respond to fire calls and uneconomical to repair. These trucks are needed by all the Installation Management Command (IMCOM) Regions: Atlantic, Central, Pacific, Korea and Europe, as well as other Army Commands and reporting Units. Examples include Structural Pumpers, Ladder Trucks, Airfield Crash Trucks, and Mobile Water Supply fire trucks.
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: FIRETRUCKS, NON-TACTICAL
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks:
The primary PCO is the Defense Logistics Agency (DLA) located in Philadelphia. However, occasionally there is equipment that is procured overseas, such as Japan or Europe, or via the General Services Administration's (GSA) multiple awards schedule.
There are multiple contractors for FY15 Structural Pumpers. These contractors include Emergency One (Ocala, FL) and Pierce Manufacturing (Appleton, WI).

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: The Family of Heavy Tactical Vehicles (FHTV) is designed for cross-country military missions to transport ammunition, petroleum, oils and lubricants, unit resupply, and other missions throughout the tactical environment to support modern and highly mobile combat units. Systems include the Heavy Expanded Mobility Tactical Truck (HEMTT) and the Palletized Load System (PLS). The HEMTT A4 and PLS A1 incorporate the Long Term Protection Strategy (LTPS) "B-Kit" Ready cab, a modern power train, independent front suspension, Anti-lock Braking System (ABS) and traction control, updated electrical system and climate control. Both trucks utilize the companion PLS-trailer (A1) with Container Transfer Enhancement (CTE), and Enhanced Container Handling Units (E-CHU). The HEMTT Light Equipment Transporter (LET) tractor is the primary recovery vehicle for the Modular Catastrophic Recovery System (MCRS) which is designed to recover catastrophically damaged Strykers and Mine-Resistant Ambush-Protected (MRAP) vehicles. The Heavy Equipment Transporter System (HETS) comprised of a tractor and trailer is also included in this family of vehicles.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $39.564 million supports a quantity of 430 M1076 PLS trailers to fill Active Army and Army National Guard components in support of Stryker and Modular Brigade Combat Teams (BCT) activations, Patriot Units, and Combat Engineers. These funds also support the installation, transportation, and fielding of ECHU kits for HEMTT LHS and PLS vehicles.
FY 2017 OCO procurement dollars in the amount of $6.122 million supports a quantity of 47 M1076 PLS trailers and a quantity of 4 HEMTT LHS for the Combatant Command (COCOM) requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries and support the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI). Procurement is necessary to outfit the Pre-Positioned equipment set. There is no excess inventory or viable substitute available to support the ERI requirement.
This is a Fixed Price Incentive - Firm (FPI-F) contract. All hardware and Federal Retail Excise Tax (FRET) unit costs are calculated at ceiling cost and awarded at target cost until delivery orders are reconciled.
System Engineering/Program Management (SEPM) includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and provide contractor oversight. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other Government costs are included for retaining a professional acquisition workforce.
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: TRAILER,PLS,8 X 20
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: Unit costs are determined by range pricing at ceiling amount for each Ordering Year (OY).

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: TRUCK CARGO TAC 8X8: HVY EXPANDED MOB W/LHS
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: Unit costs are determined by range pricing at ceiling amount for each Ordering Year (OY).

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Palletized Load System Extended Service Program (PLS ESP) is a Department of the Army (DA) supported recapitalization program critical to increasing the 16.5 ton payload to include armor capability for the 10 wheel drive PLS fleet. The PLS A1 truck contains capability for onboard Load Handling System, 16.5 ton PLS trailer, PLS Enhanced Container Handling Unit (E-CHU) for transporting 20' International Organization for Standardization containers, M3 Container Roll-in/Out Platforms (CROPs), M1077 Flatracks and M1 Flatracks in an armored configuration. The PLS ESP will remanufacture and upgrade older PLS A0s to the A1 model. The PLS A1 has improved survivability with an integrated underbody A-cab and a scalable B-kit (common to the HEMTT A4), an improved powertrain, suspension and electrical system and adds an anti-lock braking system, air conditioning and traction control. The PLS fleet is an essential force sustainment enabler in transportation and ordnance formations. This program produces a like-new vehicle with a full new vehicle warranty.
The Approved Acquisition Objective for PLS ESP is incorporated with PLS NEW at 6,956 vehicles.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $11.856 million supports recapitalization of a quantity of 5 PLS trucks to M1075A1 and 4 PLS trucks to M1074A1 configurations.
FY 2017 OCO procurement funding in the amount of $106.358 million supports recapitalization of a total of 230 PLS variants to the latest A1 configuration in support of Direct Army and Army Prepositioned Stock (APS).
FY 2017 OCO includes $79.268 million to support the COCOM requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries and support the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI). The recapitalization includes a quantity of 206 PLS trucks M1075A1 and 24 PLS trucks M1074A1 configurations. This provisions the European Reassurance Initiative - Army Prepositioned Stock (APS) which supports the establishment of Armored Brigade Combat Teams (ABCT) for ERI. Procurement is necessary to outfit the Pre-Positioned equipment set. There is no excess inventory or viable substitute available to support the ERI requirement. APS must be filled with trucks that meet armoring requirements.
FY 2017 OCO also includes $27.090 million in support of Operation Freedom's Sentinel (OFS) to recapitalize equipment returning from operations in theater. This supports the recapitalization of a quantity of 55 PLS trucks to M1075A1 to provide the bulk of refueling, resupply, and recovery capability throughout the Army. PLS Recapitalization incorporates the most urgently required production-ready technology and survivability enhancements for the warfighter.
System Engineering/Program Management (SEPM) includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and provide contractor oversight. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other Government costs are included for retaining a professional acquisition workforce.
This is a Fixed Price Incentive - Firm (FPI-F) contract. All hardware and Federal Retail Excise Tax (FRET)unit costs are calculated at ceiling cost and awarded at target cost until delivery orders are reconciled.
The Program Manager (PM) and System Synchronization Officer (SSO) may adjust quantities to take advantage of cost savings in range pricing; allowing the PM to recap additional quantities and buy to budget.
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: PLS ESP
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: Unit costs are determined by range pricing at ceiling amount for each Ordering Year (OY).

proc:LineItem.proc:LineItemTitle: Hvy Expanded Mobile Tactical Truck Ext Serv
proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Heavy Expanded Mobility Tactical Truck Extended Service Program (HEMTT-ESP) is a RECAP program critical to increasing the 11.5 ton load, 8 wheel drive HEMTT to include fleet armor ready capability. HEMTT-ESP remanufactures and upgrades 20+ year old HEMTT A0 and battle damaged A2 vehicles to the current A4 model. The HEMTT A4 has improved survivability with an integrated underbody A-cab and a scalable B-kit (common to the Palletized Load System-PLS A1); an improved powertrain, suspension and electrical system and adds an anti-lock braking system, air conditioning and traction control. The HEMTT fleet is an essential combat enabler in all Brigade Combat Team (BCT) formations. This program produces a like-new vehicle with a full new vehicle warranty.
Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO) for HEMTT ESP is incorporated with HEMTT new at 20,077.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
There are no FY 2017 Base procurement funding requirements for this program.
FY 2017 OCO procurement funding in the amount of $203.766 million supports recapitalization of a total of 446 HEMTT variants to the latest A4 configuration in support of Direct Army and Army Prepositioned Stock (APS).
The FY 2017 OCO includes $76.561 million to support the COCOM requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries and support the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI). The recapitalization includes qty 41 M984A4 Wrecker, qty 46 M978A4 Tanker, and qty 84 M985A4 Cargo and supports European Reassurance Initiative - Army Prepositioned Stock (APS) which supports the establishment of Armored Brigade Combat Teams (ABCT) for ERI. Procurement is necessary to outfit the Pre-Positioned equipment set. There is no excess inventory or viable substitute available to support the ERI requirement. APS must be filled with trucks that meet armoring requirements.
FY 2017 OCO also includes $127.205 million in support of Operation Freedom's Sentinel (OFS) to recapitalize equipment returning from operations in theater. This includes qty 63 M985A4 Cargo, qty 73 M983A4 Tractor, qty 103 M1120A4 LHS, qty 26 M984A4 Tractor, and qty 10 M985E1 GMT to provide the bulk of refueling, resupply, and recovery capability throughout the Army. HEMTT Recapitalization incorporates the most urgently required production-ready technology and survivability enhancements for the warfighter and will fill shortages and modernization for Active Army units.
System Engineering/Program Management (SEPM) includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and provide contractor oversight. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other Government costs are included for retaining a professional acquisition workforce.
FY 2017 PM Support has been increased to cover the final year of procurement funding for HEMTT ESP. This funding is to cover two years of PM Support to transition the program into sustainment.
This is a Fixed Price Incentive - Firm (FPI-F) contract. All hardware and Federal Retail Excise Tax (FRET) unit costs are calculated at ceiling cost and awarded at target cost until delivery orders are reconciled.
The Program Manager (PM) and System Synchronization Officer (SSO) may adjust quantities to take advantage of cost savings in range pricing; allowing the PM to recap additional quantities and buy to budget.
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: Hvy Expanded Mobile Tactical Truck Ext Serv
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks: Unit costs are determined by range pricing at ceiling amount for each Ordering Year (OY).

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Heavy Tactical Vehicle (HTV) Protection Kit program provides Armor Survivability Suite protection. HTV Protection Kits include B-Kits (with underbody protection), Fire Suppression, Fuel Tank Fire Suppression (FTFS) Blanket , Fuel Tank Self Sealant (FTSS), and Tank Armor Module (TAM) to enhance survivability. The Armor Survivability Suite components are mounted to an A-Kit Heavy Tactical Vehicle; which includes Heavy Expanded Mobility Tactical Truck (HEMTT), Heavy Equipment Transporter System (HET), Palletized Load System (PLS), Heavy Dump Truck (HDT), and Line Haul configurations to address numerous threats that the DoD has identified. The Armor Survivability Suite provides occupant protection through enhanced tactical vehicle ballistic protection.
The Medium Tactical Vehicles (MTV) Protection Kit Suite includes an Armor Kit and a Fuel Tank Fire Suppression (FTFS) system. The Armor Kit consists of applique armor panels that are mounted to the FMTV A-Cab exterior to further improve occupant survivability from attack. The FTFS is a ballistic fire protection system designed to cover the fuel tank on the LTAS FMTV. The MTV Protection Kit Suite provides occupant protection through enhanced tactical vehicle ballistic protection. ISO containers are inclusive to facilitate long term storage.
Protection kits were previously part of DA0500 (Family of Heavy Tactical Vehicles) and D15500 (Family of Medium Tactical Vehicles).
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $49.751 million procures 647 Armor Survivability Suite Protection Kits for Heavy Tactical Vehicles and 344 Protection Kits for Medium Tactical Vehicles to support Active Army units.
FY 2017 OCO procurement dollars in the amount of $101.154 million procures 880 Armor Survivability Suite Protection Kits for Heavy Tactical Vehicles and 492 Protection Kits for Medium Tactical Vehicles to support Active Army units.
Heavy Tactical Vehicle FY 2017 OCO funding in the amount of $74.035 million is required to support Operation Freedom's Sentinel (OFS) to replace combat losses and washouts from combat operations in theater. The OFS procurement includes 755 Protection Kits for Heavy Tactical Vehicles.
Heavy Tactical Vehicle FY 2017 OCO funding in the amount of $5.906 million is required to support the Combatant Command (COCOM) requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries and support the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI) in outfitting the pre-positioned equipment sets. There is no excess inventory or viable substitute available to support the ERI requirement. The ERI procurement includes 125 Protection Kits for Heavy Tactical Vehicles.
Medium Tactical Vehicles FY 2017 OCO funding includes $21.213 million to support the COCOM requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries and support the European Reassurance Initiatives (ERI). The ERI procurements include 492 Protection Kits for Medium Tactical Vehicles.
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: HEAVY TACTICAL VEHICLE PROTECTION KITS
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks:
February 2017 is the last ordering year for Fidelity Technologies. A follow on contract is to be determined upon completion of competitive bid process with target award date of June 2017.
Production rates and lead times are an estimate for the TBD contractor.
Fluctuation in unit cost is caused by model mix.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
This line funds the Army's plan to recapitalize Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) RG33L+ variant vehicles originally bought to fill Operational Needs Statement (ONS) or Joint Operational Needs Statement (JUONS) into Program of Record (PoR) Panther Medium Mine Protected Vehicle (MMPV) Type I (a 6X6 vehicle). In addition, this line implements the Army's plan to upgrade a mix of ONS/JUONS vehicles: Husky, Panther-MMPV Type I, Buffalo, and RG31-MMPV Type II (a 4X4 vehicle) in conjunction with a reset program to field PoR vehicles to Engineer Companies; Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear, Explosive (CBRNE) Units; Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) Units; and Area Clearance Platoons.
Funding supports modifications to upgrade the Palletized Load System Trailer (PLST) with Container Transfer Enhancement (CTE). The CTE enables the PLST to directly transload standard 20 foot ISO containers from Container Handling Unit (CHU) equipped vehicles without the need of additional flatrack or Materiel Handling Equipment (MHE). The CTE consists of 3 components: the front ISO locks, the cart, and the rear bumper.
Funding supports modifications to equip the Palletized Load System (PLS) with active safety hardware referred to as the By-Wire Active Safety Kit (BWASK). The kit consists of multiple sensors, radars, electronic steering, electronic actuators, and software processing controllers. When integrated on a vehicle, the kit provides enhanced safety features to the operator such as blind spot monitoring, forward and rear obstacle detection, collision mitigation and adaptive cruise control. The kit is comprised of commercial hardware tailored for use in a military environment and operation on the M1074A1 and M1075A1 PLS.
Funding supports the Heavy Equipment Transporter (HET) modification study for increased payload and testing.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars of $50.802 million supports the Army's plan for recapitalization-production of 13 Panther MMPV Type I (Army Acquisition Objective of 587), 4 Buffalo (AAO 338), and 10 Husky (AAO 673). Systems Technical Support of Route Clearance Vehicles fleet funds existing contracts with original equipment manufacturers (OEM) to support vehicle recapitalization at Letterkenny Army Depot, Chambersburg, Pennsylvania. Funding also supports fielding of previously procured Route Clearance Vehicles and required spare parts. Additionally, Interim Contractor Logistic Support (ICLS) for all Route Clearance Vehicles will be funded until operation and maintenance manuals allows for organic (Soldier) sustainment. Procurement of Government Furnished Equipment (GFE) includes: Objective Gunner Kits, Drivers Vision Enhancement, Vehicle Internal Communication and A kits for radios, Blue Force Tracker, Defense Advanced Global Positioning System Receiver, jammers, chemical alarms.
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars of $13.198 million funds hardware and installation of 377 CTE Kits for Heavy Tactical Vehicle's PLS Trailers. Funds support BWASK procurement of test assets and contract logistic documentation. CTE and BWASK System Engineering/Program Management (SEPM) includes PM and System Engineering oversight required to manage the program and contractors. Salaries, Benefits, Travel, Personnel Training and other Government costs are included for retaining a professional acquisition workforce. Funds support the Heavy Equipment Transporter (HET) modification study for increased payload and testing.
FY 2017 OCO procurement dollars of $153.524 million supports the Army's plan for recapitalization-production of 221 Medium Mine Protected Vehicle Type II MMPV Type II (AAO 929). In support of the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI), the Army's plan is for recapitalization-production of 4 Husky (AAO 673). Procurement of GFE includes: Objective Gunner Kits, Drivers Vision Enhancement, Vehicle Internal Communication and A kits for radios, Blue Force Tracker, Defense Advanced Global Positioning System Receiver, jammers, chemical alarms. Equipment Costs include Vehicle Protection kits, training targets, and Multi-functional Video Displays to be kitted on FY17 and prior year production vehicles.
FY 2017 OCO procurement dollars of $1.932 million supports the Combatant Command (COCOM) requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries in support ERI which provides for the hardware and installation of 120 CTE Kits on PLS trailers. In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P3AModificationItemGroup.proc:Description:
This line funds the Army's plan to recapitalize Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) RG33L+ variant vehicles originally bought to fill Operational Needs Statement (ONS) or Joint Operational Needs Statement (JUONS) into Program of Record (PoR) Panther Medium Mine Protected Vehicle (MMPV) Type I (a 6X6 vehicle). In addition, this line implements the Army's plan to upgrade a mix of ONS/JUONS vehicles: Husky, Panther-MMPV Type I, Buffalo, and RG31-MMPV Type II (a 4X4 vehicle) in conjunction with a reset program to field PoR vehicles to Engineer Companies; Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear, Explosive (CBRNE) Units; EOD Units; and Area Clearance Platoons.
Funding also supports modifications to upgrade the Palletized Load System Trailer (PLST) with Container Transfer Enhancement (CTE). The CTE enables the PLST to directly transload standard 20 foot ISO containers from Enhanced Container Handling Unit (ECHU) equipped vehicles without the need of additional flatrack or Materiel Handling Equipment (MHE). The CTE consists of 3 components: the front ISO locks, the cart, and the rear bumper.
Funding supports modifications to equip the Palletized Load System (PLS) with active safety hardware referred to as the By-Wire Active Safety Kit (BWASK). The kit consists of multiple sensors, radars, electronic steering, electronic actuators, and software processing controllers. When integrated on a vehicle, the kit provides enhanced safety features to the operator such as blind spot monitoring, forward and rear obstacle detection, collision mitigation and adaptive cruise control. The kit is comprised of commercial hardware tailored for use in a military environment and operation on the M1074A1 & M1075A1 truck variants. The BWASK will be installed onto PLS trucks as a permanent modification to the entire fleet.
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $50.802 million supports the Army's plan for recapitalization-production of 13 Panther MMPV Type I in support the (AAO 587), 4 Buffalo (AAO 338) and 10 Husky (AAO 673). Systems Technical Support of Route Clearance Vehicles fleet funds the existing contracts with original equipment manufacturers to support vehicle recapitalization at Letterkenny Army Depot, Chambersburg, Pennsylvania. Funding also supports continued fielding of previously procured Route Clearance Vehicles and required spare parts, and provides Interim Contractor Logistic Support (ICLS)in support of all Route Clearance Vehicles until operation and maintenance manuals allows for organic sustainment. Procure GFE and equipment - GFE includes Objective Gunner Kits, Drivers Vision Enhancement, Vehicle Internal Communication and A kits for radios, Blue Force Tracker, Defense Advanced Global Positioning System Receiver, jammers, and chemical alarms.
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $13.198 million supports the CTE Upgrade for Heavy Tactical Vehicle's PLS Trailers, BWASK Kits for PLS vehicles, and HET modification study for increased payload and testing.
FY 2017 OCO procurement dollars in the amount of $153.524 million supports the Army's plan for recapitalization-production of 221 MMPV Type II ( AAO 929).In addition 4 Husky (AAO 673) to support the European Reassurance Initiative(ERI). Additional OCO requirements include Systems Technical Support of Medium Mine Protected Vehicle Type II which funds the existing contracts with original equipment manufacturers to support vehicle recapitalization at Letterkenny Army Depot, Chambersburg, Pennsylvania. Procurement of Government Furnished Equipment and equipment - GFE includes Objective Gunner Kits, Drivers Vision Enhancement, Vehicle Internal Communication and A kits for radios, Blue Force Tracker, Defense Advanced Global Positioning System Receiver, jammers, and chemical alarms. Equipment Costs include Vehicle Protection kits and Multi-functional Video Displays (includes prior year quantities) and training targets.
FY 2017 OCO procurement dollars in the amount of $1.932 million supports the Combatant Command (COCOM) requirement for unit equipment sets to deter potential adversaries in support of the European Reassurance Initiative (ERI) which provides for the hardware and installation of 120 CTE Kits on PLS trailers.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: This budget line implements the Army's plan to synchronize the reset and upgrade to common configurations of the Mine Resistant, Ambush Protected (MRAP) fleet returning from theater for Army enduring requirements, as well as produce/procure materiel solutions to evolving threats in response to urgent warfighter requirements. These vehicles were originally procured in response to Operational Needs Statements, Joint Urgent Operational Needs Statements, and Universal Urgent Needs Statements to meet wartime requirements to mitigate the effects of Improvised Explosive Devices, underbody mines, rocket propelled grenades, and small arms threats. The Army MRAP enduring requirement is 8,585 vehicles. All other MRAP variants will be divested.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY17 Base $10.6 million funds will support initial contractor logistics support to Table of Organization and Equipment units and training locations (MRAPs for institutional, home station and post-mobilization training).
"In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:P3AModificationItemGroup.proc:Description:
This budget line implements the Army's plan to synchronize the reset and upgrade to common configurations of the Mine Resistant, Ambush Protected (MRAP) fleet returning from theater for Army enduring requirements, as well as produce/procure materiel solutions to evolving threats in response to urgent warfighter requirements. These vehicles were originally procured in response to Operational Needs Statements, Joint Urgent Operational Needs Statements, and Universal Urgent Needs Statements to meet wartime requirements to mitigate the effects of Improvised Explosive Devices, underbody mines, rocket propelled grenades, and small arms threats. The Army MRAP enduring requirement is 8,585 vehicles. All other MRAP variants will be divested.
FY17 Base $10.6 million funds will support initial contractor logistics support to Table of Organization and Equipment units and training locations (MRAPs for institutional, home station and post-mobilization training).
"In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: These physical security vehicles are specialized commercial design vehicles that are armored to meet specific threat conditions within the guidelines/requirements established by the Office of the Secretary of Defense, Special Operations and Low Intensity Conflict (SOLIC) for Heavy Armored Vehicles (HAV). These vehicles provide inconspicuous protection and transportation for U.S. personnel and cargo in high threat areas, such as Europe, Korea, and Southwest Asia. The level of armor is in accordance with the nature and type of threat in the area of use. These vehicles are heavy duty passenger vehicles and are utilized by General Officers, dignitaries, embassy personnel, and other servicemen requiring protection. These vehicles are essential for protecting lives. Heavy Armored Sedan is a vehicle replacement program that does not have a set Army Acquisition Objective (AAO). Procurements are made when requirements arise based on threat conditions or when existing vehicles need to be replaced due to unserviceable condition or over-age and over-mileage status.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $0.394 million supports the physical security of High Resource Personnel (HRP) in areas of threat, such as Europe, Korea, Africa, and Southwest Asia. Vehicle replacements are needed in Europe to ensure the continued protection of General Officers and visiting dignitaries.
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: This line is a roll-up of sedans, ambulances and 12 to 90 passenger-size buses. Passenger Carrying Vehicles are of commercial design intended to provide transportation for Army personnel and family members. This program procures vehicles for Outside Continental United States (OCONUS) activities, such as Japan, Korea and Honduras, where General Services Administration (GSA) fleet leased vehicles are not available. Passenger Carrying Vehicles are procurable from commercial vendors, Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEM) and after-market sources. This is a vehicle replacement program that does not have a set Army Acquisition Objective (AAO). Procurements are made to replace Passenger Carrying Vehicles when they reach an over-aged or unserviceable condition.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
There are no FY 2017 Base procurement dollars for this program.
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: This line is a roll-up of Special Purpose Vehicles and General Purpose Vehicles. Special and General Purpose vehicles are used in the direct support of facility engineering, maintenance activities, and for general administrative use in transporting personnel and cargo. All vehicles are procurable from commercial sources. Non-Tactical Vehicles is a vehicle replacement program that does not have a set Army Acquisition Objective (AAO). Procurements are made to fill shortages or to replace vehicles that have reached an over-aged or unserviceable condition.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2017 Base procurement dollars in the amount of $1.755 million supports installations and units with Non-Tactical Vehicles providing cargo and passenger transportation, in addition to facility engineering and maintenance capability. 19 Non-Tactical Vehicles are required to fill shortages and replace over-aged vehicles that are unsafe, over mileage, or uneconomical to repair. The 19 vehicles include 10 general purpose vehicles and 9 special purpose vehicles. Among the General Purpose Vehicle types required are carryalls, stake trucks, cargo trucks, tractor trucks, and light armored vehicles. These vehicles are needed at Outside the Continental United States (OCONUS) locations where General Services Administration (GSA) leasing is not available (e.g. Japan and Korea). Most Special Purpose Vehicles are not available from GSA to lease; therefore, support to the servicing, sanitation, and welfare missions of the field must be provided by procurement. Service platform trucks, dump trucks, and other special purpose vehicles are required to continue the engineering support mission necessary to the operation of posts, camps, and stations worldwide. An assessment will be made by the program office during the year of execution on the specific type of Non-Tactical Vehicles to be procured to meet current operational requirements.
All funding goes to the Active Component.
In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.
The FY 2017 funding request was reduced by $1.104 million to account for the availability of prior year execution balances.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: GENERAL PURPOSE VEHICLES
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks:
There are multiple contracts, contractors, and PCOs for General Purpose Vehicles. The primary PCO is General Services Administration in Washington, DC. However, other PCO sources are also utilized to procure vehicles, such as Army Contracting(Warren, MI), Defense Logistics Agency (Philadelphia, PA), and regional Army or Department of Defense Contracting agencies. The Theater Contracting Command in Europe is utilized to purchase vehicles for requirements in Europe.
There are multiple contractors for FY15 Cargo Trucks, Carryall Trucks, Tractor Trucks, Stake Trucks, Panel Trucks, and Utility Vehicles. These contractors include the following: Ford Motor Company (Dearborn, MI), Grande Ford Truck Sales (Dripping Springs, TX), Kig Vehicle Concepts (Arlington, VA), Herbert Neff GMBH (Germany), AB Automotive NV (Belgium), Toyota Motor Corporation (Japan), Okinawa Mazda Hanbai (Japan), and SMA Support Co. (Japan).

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: SPECIAL PURPOSE VEHICLES
proc:P5Item.proc:OverallHistoryPlanningRemarks:
There are multiple contracts and contractors for Special Purpose Vehicles. The primary PCO is General Services Administration in Washington, DC. Delivery orders are placed against these GSA contracts by Army contract agencies. Occasionally other PCO sources are utilized to procure vehicles that are not available on GSA contract, such as TACOM (Warren, MI), Defense Logistics Agency (Philadelphia, PA), and regional Army or Department of Defense Contracting agencies. The Theater Contracting Command in Europe is utilized to purchase vehicles for requirements in Europe.
There are multiple contractors for FY15 Dump Trucks, FY15 Servicing Platform Trucks, and FY15 Multipurpose Trucks. These contractors include the following: Time Manufacturing (Waco, TX), American Material Handling (Watkinsville, GA), Hematec Arbeitsbuhnen GMBH (Germany), Iveco Sud-West (Germany), Iveco Belgium, Herbert Neff GMBH (Germany), Michael Renka GMBH (Germany), Baywa Aktiengesellschaft (Germany), Wilhem Mayer GMBH (Germany), Beutlhauser-Bassewitz GMBH (Germany), and Henne-Unimog GMBH (Germany).
